title: Abstract Wikipedia Frame Schema — Relational: Temporal Relation
description: JSON shape for the temporal relation frame, corresponding to the `relation.temporal` family in the frame inventory and the TemporalRelationFrame dataclass from docs/FRAMES_RELATIONAL.md. This frame captures ordering and duration relations between events, states, entities, or abstract time spans (e.g. 'X happened before Y', 'X has been ongoing since 2010').

frame_type.description: Frame family identifier. For temporal relation frames the canonical value is `relation.temporal`.

id.description: Optional stable identifier for this frame instance (e.g. an internal ID, page ID, or statement cluster ID).

left.description: Left-side argument of the temporal relation. May be an event, an entity standing for an implicit event/state (e.g. 'the war'), or a TimeSpan-like temporal anchor.

right.description: Right-side argument of the temporal relation. May be an event, an entity standing for an implicit event/state, or a TimeSpan-like temporal anchor.

relation.description: Temporal relation between left and right. Typical values include 'before', 'after', 'since', 'until', 'during', 'around', 'overlapping'. The schema does not enforce a closed set, but downstream logic may normalize these.

left_time.description: Optional explicit time span associated with the left argument, if not already encoded in the referenced event or entity.

right_time.description: Optional explicit time span associated with the right argument, if not already encoded in the referenced event or entity.

recurrence.description: Optional recurrence label for seasonal or periodic relations (e.g. 'annual', 'monthly', 'every_July').

certainty.description: Confidence score in the relation, between 0 and 1. Used for soft / approximate temporal facts.

source_id.description: Optional source identifier for this relation (e.g. citation key, dataset row ID).

extra.description: Arbitrary extra metadata carried through normalization; not interpreted by the generic NLG layer but preserved for traceability and debugging.

EntityRef.description: Lightweight reference to a discourse entity, following the shape of semantics.types.Entity.

id.description: Stable identifier for the entity, e.g. a Wikidata QID ('Q42'), local database ID, or URI.

name.description: Preferred surface name or label, such as 'World War II' or 'Treaty of Paris'.

gender.description: Coarse gender category for human entities (e.g. 'female', 'male', 'nonbinary', 'unknown').

human.description: Whether this entity is a human (useful for pronoun selection).

entity_type.description: Optional coarse type hint such as 'person', 'organization', 'place', 'event', 'concept'.

lemmas.description: Optional list of lemma-like labels associated with the entity.

features.description: Arbitrary feature dictionary for morphology / constructions (e.g. grammatical person, number, animacy).

extra.description: Arbitrary metadata (IDs, codes, raw source row, etc.).

LocationRef.description: Reference to a location, following the shape of semantics.types.Location. May appear inside referenced events, but is not used directly in the temporal frame properties.

id.description: Stable identifier for the location (e.g. QID, geocode).

country_code.description: Optional ISO country code, such as 'FR'.

features.description: Arbitrary feature dictionary, e.g. for preposition choice.

TimeSpan.description: Coarse time span or single date, following semantics.types.TimeSpan. Used to represent explicit temporal anchors and durations.

start_year.description: Starting year, e.g. 1914. For a single date, this is the main year of interest.

approximate.description: If true, the timespan is approximate (e.g. 'around 1800').

EventRef.description: Lightweight reference to a semantic event (semantics.types.Event), such as a war, treaty, project, or festival.

event_type.description: Free-form event type label, such as 'war', 'treaty', 'project', 'festival'.

time.description: When the event took place (optional if represented elsewhere).

location.description: Where the event took place (entity or location).

participants.description: Optional mapping from participant roles (e.g. 'subject', 'belligerent', 'signatory') to entities involved in the event.
